title: Thomas E. Dewey
added: Roger Masters, a professor of government at Dartmouth College, wrote: "The shaved face has become a reflection of the [[Protestant ethic]]. Politicians are supposed to control nature in some sense, so beards and mustaches, which imply a reluctance to control nature, are now reserved for [[artisans]] or [[academics]]."<ref name="LATimes103188">{{Cite news|last=OLIN|first=DIRK|url=https://articles.latimes.com/1988-10-31/local/me-469_1_facial-hair|title=In Politics, the Mustache Is the Kiss of Death|date=1988-10-31|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2016-01-01|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>{{Efn|"Since 1912, the Oval Office has not been gained by anyone bearing so much as mutton chop, goatee or fu man chu. And it's been 40 years since the either party has even nominated a facially hirsute candidate."<ref name=LATimes103188/>}}
